awd_titl_txt: Modeling Long-Term Urban and Rural Settlement Dynamics
awd_abstract_narration:
This award was provided as part of NSF's Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences (SBE) Postdoctoral Research Fellowships (SPRF) program. The goal of the SPRF program is to prepare promising, early career doctoral-level scientists for scientific careers in academia, industry or private sector, and government. SPRF awards involve two years of training under the sponsorship of established scientists and encourage Postdoctoral Fellows to perform independent research. NSF seeks to promote the participation of scientists from all segments of the scientific community, including those from underrepresented groups, in its research programs and activities; the postdoctoral period is considered to be an important level of professional development in attaining this goal. Each Postdoctoral Fellow must address important scientific questions that advance their respective disciplinary fields. Under the sponsorship of Dr. Carla Klehm at the University of Arkansas, Fayetteville, this postdoctoral fellowship award supports an early career scientist studying urban-rural dynamics. This project investigates the social processes of urbanization within a regional settlement system. It advances scientific knowledge on these aspects of human social and organizational behavior through a long-term archaeological study. This research contributes to general knowledge about rural and urban social change by investigating the spatial settlement patterns of communities which differentiated themselves from urban institutions and negotiated with the centralization of power in urban centers. How small human groups related socially to the emergence of urban formations has been an important anthropological question with implications for understanding long-term sustainability and resilience. However, most research has used examples from primary centers of urban formation globally. In contrast, this research deepens an understanding of urban-rural interaction through a consideration of large urban centers over the long-term. The results of this research will inform general understandings of human adaptations to social transformation and political instability globally.

This project uses archaeological methods and geospatial analyses to understand the spatial and material relationships between rural communities and large urban settlements, from the 11th to 19th centuries CE. The extent to which urbanization meant the (dis)integration or subordination of indigenous rural social networks is unresolved, as are the ways rural communities related to the social world. This research will refine models of global urbanism by investigating rural settlement dynamics in relation to urban development over time. The project asks, to what extent were rural communities entangled economically and materially with town dwellers, and how did urban-rural settlement dynamics change from the precolonial period, through colonial contact, and into the 19th century? This project uses low-cost, high-resolution aerial and multispectral satellite imagery to create a predictive model for rural site distribution, integrating historical maps, textual sources, hydrological models, geological data, and automated object-based image analysis of drone imagery to detect cultural significant features. Next, the project uses this model to develop a targeted survey of the urban hinterland. Finally, test excavations will be used to compare material culture from rural hinterland sites with already excavated collections from urban centers. This will enable an understanding of the spatial and material patterns across time and in relation to urban centers.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The NSF award 2204149 resulted in the successful completion of two years of methodological development, fieldwork, and data analysis as part of Dr. Wolfgang Alders’ postdoctoral fellowship at the Center for Advanced Spatial Technologies, at the University of Arkansas, Fayetteville. Starting in 2022, Dr. Alders assembled geospatial and environmental data to create an archaeological predictive model for site survey in the rural areas of Unguja Island, in Zanzibar, Tanzania. Using multitemporal satellite imagery, Dr. Alders planned field surveys based on this model within the interstices of the rapidly urbanizing areas of Zanzibar City, to detect evidence for rural settlement shifts that could be compared to phases of urban change on the island. Systematic field surveys carried out in 2023 identified over 50 new archaeological sites in a 15 km radius around Zanzibar City’s old town, spanning from the 8th-19th centuries CE in date. Targeted excavations in 2024 produced more in-depth data related to rural lifeways, exchange, and craft production in the rural places around the urban center.

An innovative methodological achievement of this project was the integration of geospatial technology, satellite remote sensing, and archaeological field surveys to systematically investigate archaeological landscapes across a rapidly urbanizing modern African city for the first time. While previous studies of urban centers on the East African coast have largely focused on abandoned sites of the precolonial period, this project advances the field of archaeology by investigating an urban landscape which persisted from the precolonial period to the present day. This addresses a bias in archaeology, where studies of urbanism have largely ignored ancient urban centers that endured through colonialism and developed into the modern cities of the present period.

Archaeologists typically investigate ancient urban sites in places that are presently rural, because these places are relatively easy to survey and map. But Africa, and the world as a whole, is rapidly urbanizing, so developing interdisciplinary methods to assess and record archaeological features in urbanizing modern landscapes will become critically important for archaeological research in the future. Multitemporal satellite data, capturing landscape change at a decadal, yearly, seasonal, and daily scale, is critical for this type of work. In this study, the combination of multitemporal satellite data with more traditional archaeological survey methods and predictive modeling enabled archaeological prospection of settlement patterns across a modern cityscape in a novel way. This methodology may be applied more broadly to study settlement systems globally where similar imagery is available and modern urban settlements obscure traces of past settlement systems.  Even beyond archaeology, the methods and models of this project may be applied elsewhere to record and map significant features in rapidly urbanizing places; for instance, threatened ecological habitats, hydrological systems, or changes in the use of social space.

Through data gathered from these surveys, this project has produced novel understandings of human adaptation during periods of social stratification, colonialism, and economic integration. The project gives insights into how rural communities adapted to past periods of social uncertainty and changing socio-political systems. Crucially, socioecological diversification in rural settlement trends appears to correspond with phases of urban growth, suggesting that environmental resilience in small-scale rural communities may have been tied to long-term urban persistence. These results may serve as a usable model for sustainable urban futures in Africa and beyond.

The project benefitted Zanzibari communities by documenting and mapping rural archaeological sites for conservation and heritage management, which represent real increases in cultural tourism. Through public talks given by Dr. Alders in Arkansas, New York, California, and Missouri, results from this project have also been disseminated to wider American audiences interested in understanding African history and social change.

Finally, this research project created capacity in interdisciplinary scientific research in Tanzania and the United States by training Tanzanian and American researchers in the use of low-cost GNSS hardware for high resolution site mapping, low-cost aerial and satellite imagery analysis in GIS, spatial analysis, and archaeological methods.
